update.description:
This uses

```
#!c++

[rendering]
stereo=1/0
```

in `gui.ini` to enable/disable stereo rendering.

This also updates Gazebo to work with Ogre 1.10 (heightmap changes).

[Jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/436/)
update.title: Merge haptix branch with default

content.raw: Agreed. Perhaps in the future we can consult @iche033 if it's possible to clock up the render rate without throttling the GUI.
content.html: Agreed. Perhaps in the future we can consult @iche033 if it's possible to clock up the render rate without throttling the GUI.

content.raw: Ok. I'm inclined to leave the value as `1000.0/30.0`. There is a possibility that we are doing something wrong with QT, but it's outside the scope of this pull request and we don't know for sure.
content.html: Ok. I'm inclined to leave the value as 1000.0/30.0. There is a possibility that we are doing something wrong with QT, but it's outside the scope of this pull request and we don't know for sure.

content.raw: Done in 56d61e4
content.html: Done in 56d61e4

content.html: Done in 56d61e4

content.raw: This one is wrong. It should be `== 1`, instead of `> 1`. Fixing now.
content.html: This one is wrong. It should be == 1, instead of > 1. Fixing now.

content.raw: Correct. It's a bit in error since `0.10.0` will pass. As you said we can ignore.
content.html: Correct. It's a bit in error since 0.10.0 will pass. As you said we can ignore.

content.raw: same
content.html: same

content.raw: So this logic is true for ogre `2.0` through `2.9`. Is that intended? Maybe we can put comments next to these `#if` logic blocks?
content.html: So this logic is true for ogre 2.0 through 2.9. Is that intended? Maybe we can put comments next to these #if logic blocks?

content.raw: I always have trouble reading these. Correct me if I'm wrong, otherwise ignore: this logic is true if ogre is greater than 1.9, ie. `1.10` or `2.x` (also `0.10` technically, but I assume we can ignore that).
content.html: I always have trouble reading these. Correct me if I'm wrong, otherwise ignore: this logic is true if ogre is greater than 1.9, ie. 1.10 or 2.x (also 0.10 technically, but I assume we can ignore that).

content.raw: Ok, I read the code, and this appears to be an upper bound on Rendering; the cameras will go no faster than 60 Hz (or 120 Hz with stereo). The actual limit on rendering will come from the `RenderWidget` timer.
content.html: Ok, I read the code, and this appears to be an upper bound on Rendering; the cameras will go no faster than 60 Hz (or 120 Hz with stereo). The actual limit on rendering will come from the RenderWidget timer.

content.raw:
It appears that FPS slows down when there are a lot of GUI events (clicking, button presses, etc.)

1. Max: 30.2. Resting rate appears to be 30. Lowest value I saw was 19. Gui appears responsive, though right clicking is sometimes slow (don't know if that's related to the render rate though).
Stereo works, gives me a bit of a headache.

2. Max: 62.5, resting rate appears to be 60. Lowest value I saw was 7 (!) when I clicked on an object repeatedly. Stereo works, though my eyes feel a bit out of focus, and it still gives me a headache. Gui is mostly responsive, but occasionally drops events.

3. Varies wildly from 6 to 40. GUI is comparatively very choppy. Stereo doesn't seem much worse than 2, however.
content.html:
It appears that FPS slows down when there are a lot of GUI events (clicking, button presses, etc.)

  1. Max: 30.2. Resting rate appears to be 30. Lowest value I saw was 19. Gui appears responsive, though right clicking is sometimes slow (don't know if that's related to the render rate though). Stereo works, gives me a bit of a headache.

  2. Max: 62.5, resting rate appears to be 60. Lowest value I saw was 7 (!) when I clicked on an object repeatedly. Stereo works, though my eyes feel a bit out of focus, and it still gives me a headache. Gui is mostly responsive, but occasionally drops events.

  3. Varies wildly from 6 to 40. GUI is comparatively very choppy. Stereo doesn't seem much worse than 2, however.

content.raw:
I've updated the UserCamera::GetFPS function so that it actually works. Could you(someone) run this code on the stereo rig with:

1. this->timer->start(1000.0 / 30.0)
1. this->timer->start(1000.0 / 60.0)
1. this->timer->start(1000.0 / 120.0)

Also, output the camera FPS data in this function (look at the commented code below this line).

Things to look for:

1. Is the FPS correct?
1. Is the GUI responsive?
1. Does stereo work?
content.html:
I've updated the UserCamera::GetFPS function so that it actually works. Could you(someone) run this code on the stereo rig with:

  1. this->timer->start(1000.0 / 30.0)
  2. this->timer->start(1000.0 / 60.0)
  3. this->timer->start(1000.0 / 120.0)

Also, output the camera FPS data in this function (look at the commented code below this line).

Things to look for:

  1. Is the FPS correct?
  2. Is the GUI responsive?
  3. Does stereo work?

content.raw: Done.
content.html: Done.

content.raw:
I had to look up the problem again. This originated with our custom libogre3d-1.9-dev package, which has a version number "1.10.0unstable" which is an invalid name.

Let me update the SearchForStuff cmake to construct an appropriate OGRE_VERSION for this case, and revert the check here.
content.html:
I had to look up the problem again. This originated with our custom libogre3d-1.9-dev package, which has a version number "1.10.0unstable" which is an invalid name.

Let me update the SearchForStuff cmake to construct an appropriate OGRE_VERSION for this case, and revert the check here.

content.raw: So `VERSION_GREATER` doesn't work? Is that a documented cmake issue?
content.html: So VERSION_GREATER doesn't work? Is that a documented cmake issue?

content.raw: Turns out that sort-of works as long as the ogre versions number stay as single digit numbers. The previous comparison is not actually valid.
content.html: Turns out that sort-of works as long as the ogre versions number stay as single digit numbers. The previous comparison is not actually valid.

content.raw: So here we have 60 Hz and 120 Hz, where as in RenderWidget.cc there is talk about 30 Hz. Are these related? Do they need to match?
content.html: So here we have 60 Hz and 120 Hz, where as in RenderWidget.cc there is talk about 30 Hz. Are these related? Do they need to match?

content.raw:
I think you can use `VERSION_GREATER`
~~~
if (${OGRE_VERSION} VERSION_GREATER 1.7.4)
~~~
content.html:
I think you can use VERSION_GREATER

if (${OGRE_VERSION} VERSION_GREATER 1.7.4)

content.raw: ok, thanks
content.html: ok, thanks

content.raw:
So far the latency issue is on the optitrack side of things, so we shouldn't speculate about things to change in gazebo yet.

This particular parameter is one that is very sensitive to GUI performance. Based on playing with this number in the past, I've found around 30Hz to be optimal. A higher and lower number will decrease gui responsiveness, and the actual frames per second. 

You can experiment on the stereo rig, or your own desktop. But, I wouldn't hold up this pull request on a hypothetical.
content.html:
So far the latency issue is on the optitrack side of things, so we shouldn't speculate about things to change in gazebo yet.

This particular parameter is one that is very sensitive to GUI performance. Based on playing with this number in the past, I've found around 30Hz to be optimal. A higher and lower number will decrease gui responsiveness, and the actual frames per second.

You can experiment on the stereo rig, or your own desktop. But, I wouldn't hold up this pull request on a hypothetical.

content.raw: Right, the discussion about handsim latency is why I brought up the idea of parameterizing this value: in case we want to vary it in a future latency experiment, or if we find that we need to speed up the update rate to meet our goal for latency. But if 30Hz is the optimal rendering rate, then it might not be worth parameterizing it and we can look for optimizations in other parts of the system.
content.html: Right, the discussion about handsim latency is why I brought up the idea of parameterizing this value: in case we want to vary it in a future latency experiment, or if we find that we need to speed up the update rate to meet our goal for latency. But if 30Hz is the optimal rendering rate, then it might not be worth parameterizing it and we can look for optimizations in other parts of the system.

content.raw: This isn't a demand, by the way. It's more of a question, since the issue of update rate came up during previous handsim discussions.
content.html: This isn't a demand, by the way. It's more of a question, since the issue of update rate came up during previous handsim discussions.

content.raw: Maybe a `gui.ini` setting?
content.html: Maybe a gui.ini setting?

content.raw: Is it dependent on hardware though?
content.html: Is it dependent on hardware though?

content.raw: There is a trade off with adding more parameterized values. This one in particular should not be exposed because it is very obscure, and it also does not need environment dependent tuning.
content.html: There is a trade off with adding more parameterized values. This one in particular should not be exposed because it is very obscure, and it also does not need environment dependent tuning.

content.raw: If we parameterized this value, could it be changed dynamically or can it only be set at startup?
content.html: If we parameterized this value, could it be changed dynamically or can it only be set at startup?

content.html:
When I try to compile this branch with libgazebo3d-1.9-dev for stereo support, I get to 73% and hit this error message:

/home/jackie/gazebo/gazebo/gui/model/JointMaker.cc: In member function ‘void gazebo::gui::JointMaker::CreateHotSpot(gazebo::gui::JointData*)’:
/home/jackie/gazebo/gazebo/gui/model/JointMaker.cc:596:15: error: invalid use of incomplete type ‘class Ogre::Billboard’
   parentHandle->setColour(color);
               ^
In file included from /usr/include/OGRE/Ogre.h:31:0,
                 from /home/jackie/gazebo/gazebo/rendering/ogre_gazebo.h:26,
                 from /home/jackie/gazebo/gazebo/gui/model/JointMaker.cc:24:
/usr/include/OGRE/OgrePrerequisites.h:151:11: error: forward declaration of ‘class Ogre::Billboard’
     class Billboard;
           ^
/home/jackie/gazebo/gazebo/gui/model/JointMaker.cc: In member function ‘void gazebo::gui::JointMaker::Update()’:
/home/jackie/gazebo/gazebo/gui/model/JointMaker.cc:682:44: error: invalid use of incomplete type ‘class Ogre::Billboard’
             joint->handles->getBillboard(0)->setColour(color);
                                            ^
In file included from /usr/include/OGRE/Ogre.h:31:0,
                 from /home/jackie/gazebo/gazebo/rendering/ogre_gazebo.h:26,
                 from /home/jackie/gazebo/gazebo/gui/model/JointMaker.cc:24:
/usr/include/OGRE/OgrePrerequisites.h:151:11: error: forward declaration of ‘class Ogre::Billboard’
     class Billboard;
           ^
/home/jackie/gazebo/gazebo/gui/model/JointMaker.cc:686:42: error: invalid use of incomplete type ‘class Ogre::Billboard’
           joint->handles->getBillboard(0)->setPosition(
                                          ^
In file included from /usr/include/OGRE/Ogre.h:31:0,
                 from /home/jackie/gazebo/gazebo/rendering/ogre_gazebo.h:26,
                 from /home/jackie/gazebo/gazebo/gui/model/JointMaker.cc:24:
/usr/include/OGRE/OgrePrerequisites.h:151:11: error: forward declaration of ‘class Ogre::Billboard’
     class Billboard;

perhaps our version of Ogre 1.9 doesn't support billboards, which were added in JointMaker after haptix diverged from default.
